contentrichtext.text: '''Elephantis''' (fl. late 1st century BC) was a [[Ancient Greece|Greek]] poetess apparently renowned in the classical world as the author of a notorious [[sex manual]]. Her works have not survived. ==Works== According to [[Lives of the Twelve Caesars|Suetonius]], the [[Roman Empire|Roman]] Emperor [[Tiberius]] took a complete set of her works with him when he retreated to his resort on [[Capri]].<ref>Suet. ''Tib''. 43.2.</ref> One of the poems in the ''[[Priapeia]]'' refers to her books: :''Obscenas rigido deo tabellas<br>dicans ex Elephantidos libellis<br>dat donum Lalage rogatque, temptes,<br>si pictas opus edat ad figuras.''<ref>''Priapeia'' 4.</ref> ("Lalage dedicates a votive offering to the God of the erect penis, bringing shameless pictures from the books of Elephantis, and begs him to try and imitate with her the variety of intercourse of the figures in the illustrations.")<ref name="priap">Trans. [[Leonard Smithers|L.C. Smithers]] and [[Richard Francis Burton|R.F. Burton]], ''Priapea sive diversorum poetarum in Priapum lusus, or, Sportive Epigrams on Priapus'' (1890).</ref> And an epigram by the Roman poet [[Martial]], which Smithers and Burton included in their collection of poems concerning [[Priapus]], wrote: :''Quales nec Didymi sciunt puellae,<br>Nec molles Elephantidos libelli,<br>Sunt illic Veneris novae figurae''<ref>Martial, ''Ep''. 43.1â€“4.</ref> ("Such verses as neither the daughters of Didymus know, nor the debauched books of Elephantis, in which are set out new forms of lovemaking.")<ref name="priap" /> "''Novae figurae''" has been read as "''novem figurae''" (i.e., "nine forms" of lovemaking, rather than "new forms" of lovemaking), and so some commentators have inferred that she listed nine different [[sexual positions]].{{Citation needed|date=March 2012}} She also wrote a manual about cosmetics and another about abortives.<ref>{{cite book | authors=Plant | page=118 }}</ref> ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==References== * {{cite book | title=Women writers of Ancient Greece and Rome: an anthology | author=Ian Michael Plant| year=2004 | publisher=University of Oklahoma Press }} [[Category:Ancient Greek poets]] [[Category:Ancient Greek women writers]] [[Category:Greek erotica writers]] [[Category:1st-century BC women writers]] {{Ancient-Greece-stub}} {{Poetry-stub}}
